speaker: TIMON
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: SCENE I. The woods. Before Timon's cave.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Enter Poet and Painter; TIMON watching them from his cave

speaker: Painter
text_entry: As I took note of the place, it cannot be far where

speaker: Painter
text_entry: he abides.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: What's to be thought of him? does the rumour hold

speaker: Poet
text_entry: for true, that he's so full of gold?

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Certain: Alcibiades reports it; Phrynia and

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Timandra had gold of him: he likewise enriched poor

speaker: Painter
text_entry: straggling soldiers with great quantity: 'tis said

speaker: Painter
text_entry: he gave unto his steward a mighty sum.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Then this breaking of his has been but a try for his friends.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Nothing else: you shall see him a palm in Athens

speaker: Painter
text_entry: again, and flourish with the highest. Therefore

speaker: Painter
text_entry: 'tis not amiss we tender our loves to him, in this

speaker: Painter
text_entry: supposed distress of his: it will show honestly in

speaker: Painter
text_entry: us; and is very likely to load our purposes with

speaker: Painter
text_entry: what they travail for, if it be a just true report

speaker: Painter
text_entry: that goes of his having.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: What have you now to present unto him?

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Nothing at this time but my visitation: only I will

speaker: Painter
text_entry: promise him an excellent piece.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: I must serve him so too, tell him of an intent

speaker: Poet
text_entry: that's coming toward him.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Good as the best. Promising is the very air o' the

speaker: Painter
text_entry: time: it opens the eyes of expectation:

speaker: Painter
text_entry: performance is ever the duller for his act; and,

speaker: Painter
text_entry: but in the plainer and simpler kind of people, the

speaker: Painter
text_entry: deed of saying is quite out of use. To promise is

speaker: Painter
text_entry: most courtly and fashionable: performance is a kind

speaker: Painter
text_entry: of will or testament which argues a great sickness

speaker: Painter
text_entry: in his judgment that makes it.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: TIMON comes from his cave, behind

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: [Aside]  Excellent workman! thou canst not paint a

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: man so bad as is thyself.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: I am thinking what I shall say I have provided for

speaker: Poet
text_entry: him: it must be a personating of himself; a satire

speaker: Poet
text_entry: against the softness of prosperity, with a discovery

speaker: Poet
text_entry: of the infinite flatteries that follow youth and opulency.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: [Aside]  Must thou needs stand for a villain in

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: thine own work? wilt thou whip thine own faults in

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: other men? Do so, I have gold for thee.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Nay, let's seek him:

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Then do we sin against our own estate,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: When we may profit meet, and come too late.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: True;

speaker: Painter
text_entry: When the day serves, before black-corner'd night,

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Find what thou want'st by free and offer'd light. Come.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: [Aside]  I'll meet you at the turn. What a

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: god's gold,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That he is worshipp'd in a baser temple

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Than where swine feed!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: 'Tis thou that rigg'st the bark and plough'st the foam,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Settlest admired reverence in a slave:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To thee be worship! and thy saints for aye

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Be crown'd with plagues that thee alone obey!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Fit I meet them.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Coming forward

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Hail, worthy Timon!

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Our late noble master!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Have I once lived to see two honest men?

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Sir,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Having often of your open bounty tasted,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Hearing you were retired, your friends fall'n off,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Whose thankless natures--O abhorred spirits!--

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Not all the whips of heaven are large enough:

speaker: Poet
text_entry: What! to you,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Whose star-like nobleness gave life and influence

speaker: Poet
text_entry: To their whole being! I am rapt and cannot cover

speaker: Poet
text_entry: The monstrous bulk of this ingratitude

speaker: Poet
text_entry: With any size of words.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Let it go naked, men may see't the better:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You that are honest, by being what you are,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Make them best seen and known.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: He and myself

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Have travail'd in the great shower of your gifts,

speaker: Painter
text_entry: And sweetly felt it.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Ay, you are honest men.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: We are hither come to offer you our service.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Most honest men! Why, how shall I requite you?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Can you eat roots, and drink cold water? no.

speaker: Both
text_entry: What we can do, we'll do, to do you service.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Ye're honest men: ye've heard that I have gold;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I am sure you have: speak truth; ye're honest men.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: So it is said, my noble lord; but therefore

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Came not my friend nor I.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Good honest men! Thou draw'st a counterfeit

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Best in all Athens: thou'rt, indeed, the best;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thou counterfeit'st most lively.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: So, so, my lord.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: E'en so, sir, as I say. And, for thy fiction,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Why, thy verse swells with stuff so fine and smooth

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That thou art even natural in thine art.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: But, for all this, my honest-natured friends,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I must needs say you have a little fault:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Marry, 'tis not monstrous in you, neither wish I

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You take much pains to mend.

speaker: Both
text_entry: Beseech your honour

speaker: Both
text_entry: To make it known to us.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You'll take it ill.

speaker: Both
text_entry: Most thankfully, my lord.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Will you, indeed?

speaker: Both
text_entry: Doubt it not, worthy lord.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: There's never a one of you but trusts a knave,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That mightily deceives you.

speaker: Both
text_entry: Do we, my lord?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Ay, and you hear him cog, see him dissemble,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Know his gross patchery, love him, feed him,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Keep in your bosom: yet remain assured

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That he's a made-up villain.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: I know none such, my lord.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Nor I.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Look you, I love you well; I'll give you gold,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Rid me these villains from your companies:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Hang them or stab them, drown them in a draught,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Confound them by some course, and come to me,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I'll give you gold enough.

speaker: Both
text_entry: Name them, my lord, let's know them.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You that way and you this, but two in company;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Each man apart, all single and alone,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Yet an arch-villain keeps him company.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: If where thou art two villains shall not be,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Come not near him. If thou wouldst not reside

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: But where one villain is, then him abandon.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Hence, pack! there's gold; you came for gold, ye slaves:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To Painter

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You have work'd for me; there's payment for you: hence!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To Poet

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You are an alchemist; make gold of that.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Out, rascal dogs!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Beats them out, and then retires to his cave

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Enter FLAVIUS and two Senators

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: It is in vain that you would speak with Timon;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: For he is set so only to himself

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: That nothing but himself which looks like man

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Is friendly with him.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Bring us to his cave:

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: It is our part and promise to the Athenians

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: To speak with Timon.

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: At all times alike

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: Men are not still the same: 'twas time and griefs

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: That framed him thus: time, with his fairer hand,

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: Offering the fortunes of his former days,

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: The former man may make him. Bring us to him,

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: And chance it as it may.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Here is his cave.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Peace and content be here! Lord Timon! Timon!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Look out, and speak to friends: the Athenians,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: By two of their most reverend senate, greet thee:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Speak to them, noble Timon.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: TIMON comes from his cave

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thou sun, that comfort'st, burn! Speak, and

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: be hang'd:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: For each true word, a blister! and each false

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Be as cauterizing to the root o' the tongue,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Consuming it with speaking!

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Worthy Timon,--

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Of none but such as you, and you of Timon.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: The senators of Athens greet thee, Timon.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I thank them; and would send them back the plague,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Could I but catch it for them.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: O, forget

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: What we are sorry for ourselves in thee.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: The senators with one consent of love

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Entreat thee back to Athens; who have thought

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: On special dignities, which vacant lie

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: For thy best use and wearing.

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: They confess

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: Toward thee forgetfulness too general, gross:

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: Which now the public body, which doth seldom

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: Play the recanter, feeling in itself

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: A lack of Timon's aid, hath sense withal

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: Of its own fail, restraining aid to Timon;

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: And send forth us, to make their sorrow'd render,

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: Together with a recompense more fruitful

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: Than their offence can weigh down by the dram;

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: Ay, even such heaps and sums of love and wealth

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: As shall to thee blot out what wrongs were theirs

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: And write in thee the figures of their love,

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: Ever to read them thine.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You witch me in it;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Surprise me to the very brink of tears:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Lend me a fool's heart and a woman's eyes,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And I'll beweep these comforts, worthy senators.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Therefore, so please thee to return with us

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: And of our Athens, thine and ours, to take

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: The captainship, thou shalt be met with thanks,

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Allow'd with absolute power and thy good name

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Live with authority: so soon we shall drive back

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Of Alcibiades the approaches wild,

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Who, like a boar too savage, doth root up

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: His country's peace.

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: And shakes his threatening sword

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: Against the walls of Athens.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Therefore, Timon,--

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Well, sir, I will; therefore, I will, sir; thus:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: If Alcibiades kill my countrymen,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Let Alcibiades know this of Timon,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That Timon cares not. But if be sack fair Athens,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And take our goodly aged men by the beards,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Giving our holy virgins to the stain

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Of contumelious, beastly, mad-brain'd war,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Then let him know, and tell him Timon speaks it,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: In pity of our aged and our youth,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I cannot choose but tell him, that I care not,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And let him take't at worst; for their knives care not,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: While you have throats to answer: for myself,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: There's not a whittle in the unruly camp

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: But I do prize it at my love before

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The reverend'st throat in Athens. So I leave you

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To the protection of the prosperous gods,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: As thieves to keepers.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Stay not, all's in vain.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Why, I was writing of my epitaph;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: it will be seen to-morrow: my long sickness

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Of health and living now begins to mend,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And nothing brings me all things. Go, live still;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Be Alcibiades your plague, you his,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And last so long enough!

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: We speak in vain.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: But yet I love my country, and am not

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: One that rejoices in the common wreck,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: As common bruit doth put it.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: That's well spoke.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Commend me to my loving countrymen,--

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: These words become your lips as they pass

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: thorough them.

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: And enter in our ears like great triumphers

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: In their applauding gates.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Commend me to them,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And tell them that, to ease them of their griefs,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Their fears of hostile strokes, their aches, losses,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Their pangs of love, with other incident throes

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That nature's fragile vessel doth sustain

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: In life's uncertain voyage, I will some kindness do them:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I'll teach them to prevent wild Alcibiades' wrath.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: I like this well; he will return again.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I have a tree, which grows here in my close,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That mine own use invites me to cut down,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And shortly must I fell it: tell my friends,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Tell Athens, in the sequence of degree

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: From high to low throughout, that whoso please

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To stop affliction, let him take his haste,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Come hither, ere my tree hath felt the axe,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And hang himself. I pray you, do my greeting.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Trouble him no further; thus you still shall find him.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Come not to me again: but say to Athens,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Timon hath made his everlasting mansion

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Upon the beached verge of the salt flood;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Who once a day with his embossed froth

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The turbulent surge shall cover: thither come,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And let my grave-stone be your oracle.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Lips, let sour words go by and language end:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: What is amiss plague and infection mend!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Graves only be men's works and death their gain!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Sun, hide thy beams! Timon hath done his reign.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Retires to his cave

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: His discontents are unremoveably

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Coupled to nature.

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: Our hope in him is dead: let us return,

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: And strain what other means is left unto us

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: In our dear peril.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: It requires swift foot.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Exeunt
